number of CSTRs in series
1

Directions
Details
About
Directions

This simulation displays the residence time distribution (RTD) of a compound that is injected into a continuously-stirred tank reactor (CSTR). In this simulation, multiple CSTRs are in series, such that the outlet of each CSTR is fed into the inlet of the next CSTR. A compound is pulse-injected into the first CSTR, and the plot displays the RTD of the last CSTR in the series. The RTD is a probability density function that shows the likelihood that a single particle of the injected compound will spend a certain amount of time within the last reactor. Adjust the "number of CSTRs in series" slider to change the number of CSTRs, and adjust the "spacetime" slider to change the mean residence time \( \tau = V / \upsilon \), where \( V \) is the volume of a CSTR and \( \upsilon \) is the volumetric flowrate of the liquid.

Details
A dye is pulse-injected into a CSTR or a CSTR in series, such that all of the dye enters the first CSTR within a negligibly small amount of time. The mass balance for the first CSTR in the series is
$$ [1] \quad V \frac{dC_{1}}{dt} = \upsilon \, C_{0} - \upsilon \, C_{1} $$
where \( V \) is the volume of the CSTR (L), \( C_{0} \) is the concentration of dye in the inlet stream (mol/L), \( C_{1} \) is the concentration of dye in the first CSTR's outlet stream (mol/L), \( \upsilon \) is volumetric flowrate, and \( t \) is time (s). The boundary condition is \( C_{1} = C_{init} \) at \( t = 0 \), where \( C_{init} \) is the concentration of dye in the first reactor immediately after the dye is injected (this assumes perfect mixing). \( C_{0} = 0 \) because the concentration of dye in the inlet stream is zero after the dye is injected. The equation can be rearranged and integrated (given that \( \upsilon \, C_{0} = 0 \)):
$$ [2] \quad \int_{C_{init}}^{C_{1}} \frac{d C_{1}}{C_{1}} = - \int_{0}^{t} \frac{\upsilon \, dt}{V} $$
we assign a variable for spacetime \( \tau = V / \upsilon \) and evaluate the integral:
$$ [3] \quad \mathrm{ln} \left( \frac{C_{1}}{C_{init}} \right) = - \frac{t}{\tau} $$
Solving for \( C_{1} \), we find \( C_{1} = C_{init} e^{-t/\tau} \). The mass balance for the second CSTR in the series is
$$ [4] \quad V \frac{C_{2}}{dt} = \upsilon \, C_{1} - \upsilon \, C_{2} = \upsilon \, C_{init} e^{-t/\tau} - \upsilon \, C_{2} $$
where \( C_{2} \) is the concentration of dye in the second reactor. The boundary condition for the second reactor is \( C_{2} = 0 \) at \( t = 0 \). When equation [4] is integrated, we find
$$ [5] \quad C_{2} = \frac{C_{init} \, t \, e^{-t / \tau}}{\tau} $$
This can be generalized to \( n \) reactors in series, such that \( n^{th} \) reactor's concentration of dye \( C_{n} \) is
$$ [6] \quad C_{n} = \frac{C_{init} \, t^{n - 1} \, e^{-t / \tau}}{(n - 1)! \, \tau^{n - 1}} $$
The residence time distribution (RTD) is a normalized concentration curve, such that
$$ [7] \quad \int_{0}^{\infty} E(t) \, dt = 1 $$
where \( E(t) \) is the RTD curve as a function of time and
$$ [8] \quad \frac{C_{n}}{\alpha} = E(t) $$
where \( \alpha \) is a constant. Combining equations [6], [7], and [8], then evaluating the integral, we find that \( \alpha = \tau \, C_{init} \), so the general function for RTD over time with \( n \) CSTRs is
$$ [9] \quad E_{n}(t) = \frac{t^{n - 1} \, e^{-t / \tau}}{(n - 1)! \, \tau^{n}} $$
About

This simulation was created in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, at University of Colorado Boulder for LearnChemE.com by Neil Hendren under the direction of Professor John L. Falconer. Address any questions or comments to learncheme@gmail.com. All of our simulations are open source, and are available on our LearnChemE Github repository.

Is your screen too small to fit this application? Try zooming-out on the web page (CTRL+"-" and CTRL+"=" on Windows, or ⌘+"-" and ⌘+"=" on Mac), then refreshing the page. This application is not compatible with Internet Explorer or web browsers that do not support WebGL and HTML5. Recommended browsers are the latest versions of: Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge, and Opera.
